docs.lead_paragraph: Oregon has taken new steps toward a potential lawsuit against the developers of its failed health insurance website by hiring a phalanx of lawyers and issuing demands for evidence and other material that could be used in a civil case against technology giant Oracle Corp.

headline.main: APNewsBreak: Oregon Closer to Health Exchange Suit

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York lawmaker wants to grant many of the rights of citizenship to millions of illegal immigrants and non-citizen residents, including the right to vote in local and state elections, under a bill introduced on Monday.

headline.main: N.Y. Lawmaker Aims to Give Voting Rights to Illegal Immigrants
headline.print_headline: N.Y. Lawmaker Aims to Give Voting Rights to Illegal Immigrants

docs.snippet: A New York lawmaker wants to grant many of the rights of citizenship to millions of illegal immigrants and non-citizen residents, including the right to vote in local and state elections, under a bill introduced on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven of the eight hair-hanging circus acrobats who fell to the floor during a "human chandelier" stunt in Providence last month have hired a Chicago-based law firm to represent them, the firm announced Monday.

headline.main: Injured Hair-Hanging Circus Acrobats Hire Law Firm

docs.lead_paragraph: Public support for Massachusetts’ 2006 healthcare law has remained above 60 percent despite a rocky rollout of the state’s new health insurance website, according to a poll from The Boston Globe and The Harvard School of Public Health.

headline.main: Support for Massachusetts Health Law Unscathed by Website Woes: Poll
headline.print_headline: Support for Massachusetts Health Law Unscathed by Website Woes: Poll

docs.snippet: Public support for Massachusetts’ 2006 healthcare law has remained above 60 percent despite a rocky rollout of the state’s new health insurance website, according to a poll from The Boston Globe and The Harvard School of Public Health.

docs.abstract: Food trucks are found to be as safe as restaurants. Tech start-ups head to Berlin. Are business plans over-rated?

docs.lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund cut its growth forecast for the United States on Monday and said the economy would not reach full employment until the end of 2017, allowing the Federal Reserve to bide its time before raising interest rates.

headline.main: IMF Cuts U.S. Growth Outlook, Says Full Employment Years Off
headline.print_headline: IMF Cuts U.S. Growth Outlook, Says Full Employment Years Off

docs.snippet: The International Monetary Fund cut its growth forecast for the United States on Monday and said the economy would not reach full employment until the end of 2017, allowing the Federal Reserve to bide its time before raising interest rates.

docs.lead_paragraph: The religious rights of corporations, the speech rights of abortion protesters and the privacy rights of people under arrest are among the big issues still unresolved at the Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the Barack Obama we’ve been waiting for.

headline.seo: Health Care and Climate: President Obama’s Big Deals

docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column contends Pres Obama has accomplished much in 2014, despite negative press he has received; underscores fact that Obama has made real progress on important issues like health care reform and climate change.
docs.snippet: This is the Barack Obama we’ve been waiting for.
